summary: Single-page cute/funny Valentine’s website for Sparsh, now with an intro pop-up Valentine question screen before the main wishing page.

existing_features.title: Create a single-page Valentine's Day website experience that wishes Sparsh a Happy Valentine's Day with a super cute and funny tone, including a prominent headline, a short personalized message addressing “Sparsh”, and playful microcopy throughout (all user-facing text in English).

Add lightweight interactive elements to make the page feel fun and “gift-like”, such as a button that reveals a surprise message, a small set of rotating cute/funny one-liners, and a simple animation effect (e.g., floating hearts) that does not block reading or navigation.

Implement a coherent, distinctive visual theme suitable for a Valentine’s greeting (colors, typography, layout, and decorative motifs) and apply it consistently across the page. Avoid a default/stock look; do not use a blue & purple theme.
Generate and include custom static illustration assets and render them in the UI from frontend/public/assets/generated (do not serve images from the backend).
Ensure the site is responsive and accessible: readable text contrast, keyboard-accessible buttons, sensible heading structure, and a pleasant mobile layout.
Remove the “Built with love using caffeine.ai” line (including the caffeine.ai link) from the footer at the end of the page, leaving the rest of the footer intact.
Replace every instance of the phrase “I love you” with “I like you” across all user-facing copy on the site (including hero copy and rotating one-liners).

Add an intro overlay screen that appears before the existing Valentine wishing page content, showing a full-screen rose petal animation and the question text “Will you be my Valentine?” with two options: “Yes” and “No”. Clicking “Yes” must proceed to the existing wishing page content.

Make the intro overlay “No” button playfully evade interaction: when the user tries to click/tap it, it moves away so it cannot be clicked, while remaining responsive and accessible (including reduced-motion support).
